query: What is the eligibility criteria for availing BITS Pilani International Travel Award?
reference: Full-time PhD students of the Pilani Campus, KK Birla Goa Campus, and Hyderabad Campus of BITS Pilani are eligible to submit an application for the BITS Pilani International Travel Award.  PhD students after completing two years from the date of admission are eligible for consideration for the International Travel Award.  PhD students enrolled in dual degree programs (Cotutelle programs) are not eligible for the travel award.  A PhD student can receive the International Travel Award only once during their PhD program.
answer: The eligibility criteria for availing the BITS Pilani International Travel Award includes being a PhD student of BITS Pilani, KK Birla Goa Campus, Hyderabad Campus, or Pilani Campus, and submitting an application form at least three months before the conference start date or immediately after the acceptance of the abstract or paper, whichever is earlier. The application should be submitted through the supervisor to the DRC of the research scholar. The DRC will review the application and submit a recommendation to the Selection Committee, which will meet periodically to review and select research scholars for the travel award. The Selection Committee recommendations will be considered and approved by the Director. In addition to this, the PhD student should be the first author of the paper or abstract, and the reputation of the conference where the conference is organized by a respectable Scientific Society/Association should be considered. Supervisor(s) and Doctoral Advisory Committee (DAC) members' and DRC recommendation on the progress of thesis project work in relation to the objectives approved in the thesis proposal should also be taken into account.

query: What is the maximum limit of the grant for the International Travel Award?
reference: INR 1.5 lakhs
answer: The maximum limit of the grant for the International Travel Award is not specified in the provided context.

query: What are the items which can be purchased under the contingency (with Institute PhD fellowship)?
reference: The items which can be procured under the Institute Ph.D contingency grant (for the scholars getting Institute fellowship) related to the Ph.D research work are. 1) Books and journals 2) Stationary, calculator, laser pointer, laptop mouse & cooling pad and printer cartridges 3) Supplies of computer consumables like external storage device, battery for UPS/Computers, anti- virus and other software (add-on). 4) Travel for attending conference, workshop and Lab visiting and sample collecting and CSIR NET Exams 5) Registration Examination fee for participation in professional development programs (conference, workshop, school etc and CSIR-UGC NET.) 6) Chemicals/Glassware 7) Photocopying/Typing/Binding/ charges 8) Spare parts replacement and minor repair of computers/Laptops. 9) Charges for recording spectra other experimental facility utilization charges 10) Other consumable materials required for experimental/theoretical studies 11) Data cards/ Data purchases.
answer: The items that can be purchased under the contingency with an Institute PhD fellowship can be found in the "Institute Contigency Form" and "CONTINGENCY self project" documents. These items include items purchased with a cash payment and can be claimed for reimbursement under the contingency grant. The specific items and their details can be found in the "Detail Item" columns of these forms.

query: What is a PhD student’s responsibility after bill clearance for the National Institute Travel Grant?
reference: After attending the conference/symposium, the research scholar must share their experiences and acquired knowledge with the department through a formal presentation. The Head of the Department should issue a notice for this presentation, and a copy should be submitted to the AGSRD office along with travel-related documents for bill clearance. Submit the Travel Allowance (TA) and Daily Allowance (DA) form within 15 days of the trip, including accurate travel and DA details and all original vouchers and bills. Enclosures should include the registration certificate, registration fee receipt, travel tickets, and seminar notice indicating shared knowledge from the event. If travel documents are unavailable, the accounts office will use a standard distance-based calculation from the origin to the destination. In case the visit is canceled or the grants remain unused, please let the office know in writing.
answer: The question does not directly relate to the leave policy for the institute supported PhD students. However, based on the information provided, a PhD student's responsibility after bill clearance for the National Institute Travel Grant is to perform their PhD project work at the site without a formal agreement.

query: What is the checklist for a PhD research proposal?
reference: A PhD proposal should follow this layout: General Formatting Proposed Topic of Research Objectives of Proposed Research Background of Proposed Research Methodology and Work Plan References
answer:

query: What are the guidelines for availing casual leaves by a PhD student?
reference: Casual leave is approved by the Supervisor. Casual leaves cannot be clubbed with any other leaves.
answer: According to the leave policy for institute supported PhD students, a PhD student is eligible for a casual leave of maximum 30 days per academic year. Casual leave is approved by the supervisor, and the student is expected to perform their PhD project work site without a formal agreement. The leave is allowed for medical reasons, and the student can apply for a prolonged medical leave of maximum one year without pay.

query: What is the difference between casual leaves and special casual leaves?
reference: Special casual leave is permissible for attending conferences/ workshops/ symposia/ training programmes etc. as approved by DRC while a casual leave need not be approved by the DRC. Special casual leave should not be clubbed with on duty leave or casual leave while casual leave cannot be clubbed with any other type of leaves.
answer: The difference between casual leaves and special casual leaves is the duration. Casual leaves are allowed for a maximum of 30 days, while special casual leaves are allowed for a maximum of 15 days.

query: When is an on-duty leave applicable?
reference: On duty leave is applicable when the student is expected to perform PhD project work at an off-campus site without a formal agreement.
answer: An on-duty leave is applicable when a Birla Institute of Technology and Science (BITSP) supported PhD student is required to perform their PhD project work on site but without a formal agreement. The duration of an on-duty leave is limited to 90 days.

query: How many members are present in the Departmental Research Committee (DRC)?

answer: The DRC has three members: HOD member, Chairperson, and Convener.

query: Is vertical transfer from B.Tech/M.Tech to PhD possible?
reference: Yes. Selection & recommendation of vertical transfer students should be done by the HOD/DRC, only after their source of fellowship/funding is identified and approved.
answer: No, vertical transfer from B.Tech/M.Tech to PhD is not possible as per the academic regulation clause 5 in the PhD Guideline Brochure 2019. The only options to discontinue from the PhD programme are "Registration Cancelled (RC)" or "Discontinued from the programme (DP)".

query: How much should a student secure to pass the PhD qualifying examination?
reference: The rigor & quality of Ph. D qualifying examination is the responsibility of individual DRC�s. The student has to secure a minimum of 50% in individual sub areas.
answer: The PhD qualifying examination has a format of a table with four columns: Research subarea, Marks obtained in theory, Marks obtained in Viva, and Total Marks. The total marks for the examination is 200. Therefore, a student needs to secure a minimum of 66.67 marks in the examination (200/3) to pass it.

query: What steps should be taken in case of a change in supervisor of a PhD student?
reference: A fresh approval of the University level Doctoral Counseling Committee based at Pilani, is required for any changes in topic of research and/or supervisor. Candidate has to request through supervisor and DRC to Associate Dean AGSRD, who will forward the request to Dean, AGSRD for approval of DCC/Research Board.
answer:
If a PhD student's supervisor changes, the following steps should be taken:

1. Document the change in a table with information such as the name and ID number of the old and new supervisor, the reason for the change, and the status of the topic/locale of work.
2. Obtain the signature of both the old and new supervisor on the table.
3. Notify the relevant authorities such as the university or funding body.
4. Update the DAC (Data Access Committee) with the new supervisor information.
5. Notify the PhD student and inform them of the change.
6. Confirm the change with the university or funding body.
7. Update the PhD student's records with the new supervisor information.
8. Follow up with the new supervisor to ensure a smooth transition.

query: What are the allocation percentages for Professional Development Fund (PDF), the Department Development Fund (DDF), and the Campus Development Fund (CDF) given that the overhead is less than 10% of the total budget?
answer: The allocation percentages for Professional Development Fund (PDF), the Department Development Fund (DDF), and the Campus Development Fund (CDF) are 40%, 20%, and 40%, respectively. To ensure that the overhead is less than 10% of the total budget, the sum of all charges must be less than or equal to 50% of the total budget.

query: What are the key steps involved in submitting a new research proposal?
reference: Access the GCIR website, navigate to the proposal submission section, complete the submission form, upload required documents, obtain the endorsement certificate, and finalize the submission.
answer:
To submit a new research proposal, the key steps involved are:

1. Summarize the research proposal by including the name, candidate ID, place of research work, research work organization, proposed supervisor qualification, proposed topic, objective, background, methodology, expected outcome, and summary page.
2. Format the proposed research work by including the consent organization, proposed place of research work, the necessary infrastructural and technical facilities needed for the research work, and the organization responsible for the registered program.
3. Sign the official letterhead and seal with the official certificate of the organization registered for the program.
4. Present the proposed research work to the organization and follow their submission process.
5. Carry out the research work and benefit from the organization professionally.
6. Submit the research work to the organization according to their guidelines.
7. Await the organization's decision on the acceptance of the research proposal.

By following these key steps, you can successfully submit a new research proposal.

query: How is overhead cost distributed among different funds?
reference: Overhead costs are allocated among the Professional Development Fund (PDF), Department Development Fund (DDF), and Campus Development Fund (CDF) based on a set percentage.
answer:
The overhead cost is distributed among three different funds - Professional Development Fund, Department Development Fund, and Campus Development Fund - according to their respective allocations as per the GCIR SOP Hyd 11oct table26. The allocation for each fund is as follows:

* Professional Development Fund (PDF) - 40%
* Department Development Fund (DDF) - 20%
* Campus Development Fund (CDF) - 40%

The overhead cost is calculated as a percentage of the total charges, which are the sum of the expenses and consultancy fees. The percentage of overhead cost for each fund is as follows:

* Professional Development Fund (PDF) - 30% of the total charges
* Department Development Fund (DDF) - 30% of the total charges
* Campus Development Fund (CDF) - 30% of the total charges

Therefore, the overhead cost is distributed among the three funds based on their respective allocations, with each fund contributing 30% of the total charges towards the overhead cost.

query: How is a research scholar appointed after project approval?
reference: After receiving project approval, an advertisement is issued, followed by the shortlisting of candidates, conducting interviews, and final selection with an offer letter.
answer: After obtaining approval for a research project from the relevant funding agency, the principal investigator of the project can only recruit a junior research fellow (JRF) or a senior research fellow (SRF) if the candidate holds a postgraduate degree in a basic science, graduate degree, or a professional course. The JRF is initially recruited on a monthly fellowship for two years, and the SRF is upgradable to a two-year SRF scholarship upon receiving a successful recommendation from an external expert. The annual assessment of the research fellow is mandatory, and the fellowship benefit is contingent upon satisfactory performance. The SRF period is two years, and the principal investigator must obtain formal approval and concurrence from relevant funding agencies before initiating the recruitment process for a research fellow.

query: What are the eligibility criteria for the admission in Part Time/Aspirant Ph.D programme?
reference: A person working in reputed research organizations, academic Institutes and industries, situated preferably in the close vicinity of one of the campuses of BITS Pilani, can be admitted on part time basis provided (i) the candidate is working in an organization which encourages and facilitates research (ii) candidate meets the requisite minimum qualification for admission to Ph. D programme of BITS Pilani as mentioned in (a), (b) or (c) (iii) candidate has minimum of one year work experience in related field, and (iv) candidate furnishes a "consent & no objection certificate"  from his/her parent organization. Industries and R & D Organizations collaborating with BITS can sponsor candidates to work for Ph.D under the Ph.D Aspirants Scheme. Under this Scheme such Employed professionals working in Industries and R&D Organizations having long experience and proven competence aspiring for Ph.D. programme will be considered and will be allowed to pursue their research at their own locations of work. query: Can you please give some ideas about the leave that a PhD student can avail?
reference: Each �Full- Time� candidate is eligible for 30 days of vacation and 15 days of casual leave in an academic year (August to July). Special casual leave of 15 days is permissible for attending conferences/workshop/symposiums/training programmes, etc. For female candidates, maternity leave of 90 days is permitted.
answer: A PhD student at the Birla Institute of Technology & Science, Pilani can avail of various types of leave under the institute's supported PhD students' leave policy. The maximum duration of casual leave is 30 days, special casual leave is 15 days, and duty leave is 90 days. Maternity leave is available for female candidates and can last up to 180 days. The policy also includes provisions for medical leave, which can be taken for a maximum of one year. Additionally, leaving for a fellowship or attending a training program is also permissible, subject to approval by the supervisor and the Dean of Academic Graduate Studies and Research.

query: What is the duration of the PhD programme?
reference: A student must submit his thesis within ten semesters (excluding summer terms) to be counted from the semester next to passing the qualifying examination. If the student fails to submit his thesis within stipulated period he may request the respective DRC for extension of time. Such extension for submission of thesis are limited to a maximum of four semesters. Thus, the duration for submitting final thesis (including all extensions and semester withdrawals) are limited to 14 semesters. If a candidate fails to submit his/her final thesis during this period, he/she will be discontinued from the programme. The female candidates who have availed maternity leave during this period may be given one extra semester for thesis submission.
answer: The given context does not contain any information about the duration of the PhD programme. The only information provided is related to the reasons for discontinuation and the relevant academic regulations.

query: In case I get a job, can I switch over from Full Time to Part Time PhD programme?
reference: Yes. A student admitted as Full Time scholar may be allowed to take transfer to Part time scheme provided- Students meet the basic eligibility criteria of Part Time student. Student has completed major part of his research work as certified by the supervisor and has completed at least 20 units of Ph D thesis course. The concerned Ph D supervisor, co-supervisor and respective DRC agree for such transfer.  Note: The DRC may also recommend the transfer of a student from Part-Time to Full Time category, provided research positions and stipend are available. Approval for such transfers will be granted by Dean ARD in consultation with DCC.
answer: The policy for institute-supported PhD students does not mention any provision for switching from a full-time to part-time PhD programme. However, it does mention that eligible students can apply for leave in various forms such as casual leave, special casual leave, duty leave, maternity leave, and more.
